Award.AwardTitle: TWC: Small: Scalable Hybrid Attack Graph Modeling and Analysis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cyber-physical systems (CPSs) operate nearly all of society's critical infrastructures (e.g., energy, transportation and medicine). In performing mission critical functions, CPSs exhibit hybrid (both discrete and continuous) behavior as they use digital technology to control and monitor physical processes. CPS security analysis is particularly challenging because an attacker can make use of a wide variety of vulnerabilities in the digital elements of the system (e.g., the network), the physical elements of the system, or some combination. This project is developing a mathematical and computational framework for modeling and analyzing large, complex CPSs to capture their vulnerabilities and the resulting attack paths (steps an attacker might use to disrupt the system).

This project is developing hybrid attack graphs (HAGs) as a mathematical formalism for representing security properties and compound exposures in CPSs. HAGs reflect a functional view of exposures, capturing state transitions over CPSs due to the execution of exploits in either the cyber or physical domains. As such, they offer the potential to comprehensively document a CPS attack surface. The researchers are designing HAG generation algorithms that apply intelligent search and parallelization strategies and creating a suite of web-based tools to cope with the computational burdens of large-scale CPS attack surface modeling. The project is developing an array of analytical methods, refined based on Markov Processes, classic reachability, and other techniques. To provide an experimentation platform for evaluating the project's tools and techniques, the researchers are building a CPS test bed comprised of network-controlled robotic vehicles. The testbed will also provide a competitive learning environment in which to teach students about CPS security principles in a fun and engaging manner.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cyber physical systems (CPSs) comprise critical infrastructures, biomedical devices and other mission critical systems. They exhibit hybrid behavior in discrete and continuous domains, complicating engineering and confounding analysis. Environmental and adversarial hazards threaten their safe, secure and reliable operation. This project establishes a foundation for analyzing the security properties of CPSs using a mathematical construct called a hybrid attack graph. Attack graphs adopt a functional view of exploitable exposures, chaining them to create a complete picture of a system's attack surface. Hybrid attack graphs extend traditional attack graphs by incorporating real-valued logic in the evaluation of system-exploit interactions.

The challenges associated with modeling, generating and analyzing attack graphs are exacerbated with hybrid attack graphs, where the inclusion of system components exhibiting continuous behavior dramatically expands the state space. Techniques for practical modeling, efficient generation and intelligent analysis of attack graphs have been developed. These must be applied and extended to the hybrid attack graph for it to find real utility as a tool in the hands of a security professional.

This project developed strategies and implementations for efficient hybrid attack graph generation and analysis, allowing for the full inspection of a CPS attack surface. It did so through the use of intelligent heuristics and parallel solutions.  The intelligent heuristics sought to cull the search space, while the parallel solutions explored exploiting multi-core concurrency and alternatively the inherent parallel processing power of Graphical Processing Units (GPUs). In addition, it built a suite of tools to aid in model acquisition and synthesis for CPS networks and exploits.

In order to validate the generative and analytical results produced by the hybrid attack graph applications, a gameified cyber physical system test bed was constructed.  The test bed consists of an arena populated with robotic cars engaged in a capture the flag competition. The cars, controlled remotely via laptop have custom hardware that allows for the use of Controller Area Network (CAN) protocols in order to mimic vulnerabilities found in cars driven on the road for more realistic application.  The technologies embedded in the test bed are hackable, creating opportunities for the development, exercise and analysis of blended attack vectors. The arena is fully instrumented, capturing the cyber and physical state of all actors and elements in it.  This allows for the correlation of ground truth produced by the test bed against analytical results predicted by the hybrid attack graphs.
